body.p:
When the Rev. Beth-Din in his first assembly
acknowledged the necessarity of a general Liturgy in
America, and made it so his probleme to establish
the Hebrew according to the Hebrew and vocation of the
modern time; the motiv of this problem was neither
desire of innovation nor lust of fame nor that giddy
disposition of reform, but only and simple

1. to bring unity among the members of every
congregation, as well as among all the American Sinagogues

2. to remain maintain the word of the Living God
by Moses his servent in the free land of Amerika.
The amiercan Israelite came from different countries,
and brought divers Hebrew, and this is and must be a
source of confusion, quarrel and disagreeableness in
the Synagogue and congregation. Moreover, the whole
people of Israel serves one God, reads and believes one
Thora, is inspired by one hoping, all together walking
the same way, in the same manner, leaned upon the
same support, why should be strangers to one another
by our garment? Unity is a feature of Gods divine character,
unity and peace is his holy will, unity and peace is the
end that our godly doctrine will aim! Verily I feel
myself so strangly so separated when I enter a Synagoe
that has another Hebrew, so that I can hardly fancy the
worshiping people as my jewish brethren. These
divers Hebrew, yea, those differently coloured garments built
the partition wall among Portuguise, Germain, Polish
and Bohemian Jews, and they became strange to one
another, although we all are descendants of the same
ancestors, and observe the same religios law. But the
Amerikan Jew shall know and love his brethren, and
thus that partition wall may fall in suddenly.

Moreover, it is remarkable for every feeling Israelite,
that the symptoms of a very ritual periode for our Reli-
gion appear here and there, I speak of fails that lifted
up their distorying hand against the Synagogue. Behold,
In one place the Hebrew seemed them to be wrong, unworthly
to be said, and without question or scrupulousness, without
regarding the Hebrew nor having an auhtority to undertake
a religios alteration, they expeled the Hebrew and all,
they are able to reply us, is, we did not like so many praye-
ers. In another place people understand not the hebrew
language, therefore they want to pray in the germain langu.
again without any authority. Thus the Hebrew is neglected,
and is not the neglegance of the dogmas the ruin of
the whole religion? In other places is it no question
at all to talk about such a small matter as the Syn.
is, and dislikness on the customs of the old, the ancient
songs, tans and ceremonies shut the door of the Synag. or
made the cosecrated hall of the Most High to a place of
tediousness, of profane consideration and reflection, instead
of the hall of elevation and sublimity to sanctify and adorn
our soul, we have a house for meeting. And the
consequence of those must be the ruin of the whole Religion.
Viewing those motivs for establishing a general liturgy,
I expect, that this labour would be “a felicitous mid”,
according to the doctrine of the Hebrew to unite all
the different parties and satisfying them. Be not terrified,
my orthodox brother, for that “filicitous mid”, it is evident,
that the Rev. B. D. honoured our Rabbi with this probleme,
and Rabbi Wise is, though one of the first philosophical scholars,
an orthodox talmudist, not moving one step from the
talmudical basis, and it is doubtless, that our Rabbi is the grea-
test Hebrew, who entered America. To convince you on concerning
my words I give you the principles as the basis of the liturgy

The matter is thus (read the Morate Nebuitim of Hebrew and the

commended to sacrifice him, worshipped as Deities. It was

such prayers shall not be taken up in our liturgy.
